Hi Ron, yes, I must admit my own stupidity and negelected to consult my 
books closely enough. I came across the work of the 2nd hereditary 
master Nishigaki Kanshiro in 3 books last night and think that it may 
also be possible that this is the work of a student of his. The 
simularies are numoerous, except the quality of the work with Kanshiro's 
work much finder in detail and plate. These of course could be just 
copied by another artist from another school but I am tneding to agree 
with the Nishigaki idea myself as well.

Thanks for the conversation and thought's.

Rich

Ron Hartmann wrote:

> Sorry...hit the wrong key!!!  Let me resend this...
>
> G'day Rich -
>
> My opinions are based largely on "gut feeling" when seeing the guard 
> since, on photographs at least, these groups do resemble each other. 
> Having the tsuba in-hand would of course make for a stronger argument 
> for (or against) the groups mentioned, I would think.
>
> Maybe I shouldn't had called the edge treatment "bones" but it would 
> be the lines visiable from the three-fold construction of Akasaka. 
> Last year I purchased a wonderful "willow tree" iron sukashi tsuba, 
> mumei--one of my "dream" tsuba ever since Sasano illustrated this 
> motif in his sukashi tsuba book. I felt it was Akasaka and it did have 
> these linear lines (bones?) in its edge. Jim Gilbert and Henrik 
> Eschbaum...
>
> (Was checking a spelling and accidently "sent" this...hope I got the 
> right name here!)
>
> Anyway, they did agree to Akasaka and pointed out this layering which 
> was quite evident on this tsuba. Of course, I was thrilled. In this 
> case the guard could had been Kyo-sukashi or even Higo. It brought 
> some nice discussion.
>
> As for Tosa Myochin, I have not had a lot of experience with their 
> work but do think the plate might not be a "good" compared to Akasaka. 
> They also often used the "mustache" type chiseling around the 
> nakago-ana. Your tsuba does not show this (nor does one I have that is 
> signed Tosa Myochin). When I see the surface decoration as is in your 
> tsuba, I must admit it shoots me to Nishigaki group. Interesting to 
> compare this treatment of the various Higo groups illustrated in 
> Sasano's books.
>
> Exciting tsuba, all!!  Again, sorry for the incomplete earlier email.
>
> Ron
> STL
>
